content.webTitle: Historical fiction and ‘alternative facts’ … Mantel reveals all about retelling our past

fields.headline: Historical fiction and ‘alternative facts’ … Mantel reveals all about retelling our past
fields.bodyText: Hilary Mantel’s gripping account of life in the court of Henry VIII has transformed the art of historical fiction, combining exhaustive research with imagination to produce a vivid portrayal of the tyrannical king, his wives and courtiers that has won her two Man Booker prizes and inspired an award-winning television adaptation. Now she is turning the skills she has developed in her writing to examine a much more modern theme – how fact and fiction can become confused to produce “alternative facts”. The author of Wolf Hall and Bring Up The Bodies, the first two parts of a planned trilogy charting the rise and fall of Thomas Cromwell, is using this year’s BBC Reith Lectures to explore the genre in which she made her name. She tells the Observer: “Facts and alternative facts, truth and verisimilitude, knowledge and information, art and lies: what could be more timely or topical than to discuss where the boundaries lie? “Is there a firm divide between myth and history, fiction and fact: or do we move back and forth on a line between, our position indeterminate and always shifting?” The phrase “alternative facts” has been gaining traction since the first chaotic media briefing by US president Donald Trump’s press secretary, Sean Spicer, who cited figures that were widely denounced as falsehoods. A White House colleague, Kellyanne Conway, defended him by saying he had been presenting alternative facts. In a world away from the frenzied atmosphere of contemporary US politics, Mantel will take the podium on Monday for the first of five lectures around the UK and in Belgium. Titled Resurrection: The Art and Craft, they will be broadcast over the course of the summer from 13 June on BBC Radio 4. Monday’s lecture will be recorded at Hallé St Peter’s in Manchester, a city with which Mantel has a personal link. She will argue that art can bring the dead back to life, starting with the story of her own great-grandmother. “It is apt for me to open the series in Manchester, as well as a pleasure to revisit a city that is almost home ground. I grew up on the fringe of the Peak District as a child of a mill-working family,” says Mantel, who will describe how and why she began to write fiction about the past. “In the first lecture I will talk about what I know of their Irish roots, and introduce the figure of my great-grandmother who, though she could not read or write, helped me construct my own identity as someone who reverences the past.” In a second lecture, titled The Iron Maiden and recorded at Middle Temple in London, Mantel will ask how pictures of the past are constructed and from where evidence is gleaned. She warns against two familiar errors: either romanticising the past, or seeing it as a gory horror show, adding that it is tempting but often condescending to seek modern parallels for historical events. “Are we looking into the past, or looking into a mirror?” she asks. “Dead strangers … did not live and die so we could draw lessons from them.” In two subsequent lectures, recorded in Antwerp and close to her adopted home in east Devon, she will first tell the story of how an obsessive relationship with history killed the young Polish writer Stanislawa Przybyszewska, and then delve into the practical job of getting historical fiction on to the page. “The historian will always wonder why you left certain things out, while the literary critic will wonder why you left them in,” she says. A final lecture, Adaptation, will examine how fiction changes when adapted for stage and screen, with Mantel arguing that well-written fiction does not betray history but enhances it. The same applies to theatre, film or television, according to the writer, whose work has spawned something of a mini-industry in its own right. Stage adaptations of Wolf Hall and Bring Up The Bodies have both been critically acclaimed, as has a £7m BBC television adaptation of the two by Peter Kosminsky, in which Mark Rylance plays Thomas Cromwell. Inaugurated by the BBC in 1948, the lectures mark the historic contribution made to public service broadcasting by Sir John (later Lord) Reith, the corporation’s first director general. Previous lecturers have included Bertrand Russell, Robert Oppenheimer, JK Galbraith, Aung San Suu Kyi and Stephen Hawking. Radio 4 has released the first official Reith 2017 portrait of Mantel by the award-winning photographer Richard Ansett, from a collection of images that will accompany the series. The lectures herald a departure from the relatively low public profile kept by Mantel, who nonetheless has not shied away from controversy. Speaking last month at the Oxford Literary festival, she suggested that some of her rivals in the genre of historical fiction spent their lives “in apologetic cringing” because they felt that they were “some inferior form of historian”. Separately, some commentators have filed Mantel’s imagining of the assassination of Margaret Thatcher, a short story published in 2014 described as “warped” and a “distasteful fantasy” by the Daily Mail, as alternative history.
